---
title: 'Living Labs for Public Sector Innovation: An Integrative Literature Review'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-N2X3G6KR" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Fuglsang, L., Hansen, A. V., Mergel, I., &#38; Røhnebæk, M. T. (2021). <div id="csl-bib-meta-N2X3G6KR" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-N2X3G6KR" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Fuglsang et al. conducted a review of existing research on living labs, which are collaborative spaces designed to foster innovation in the public sector. They found that while living labs are increasingly recognized for their potential, there is still confusion about what they are and how they work. By examining various studies, the authors created a model that explains how living labs contribute to public sector innovation. They also identified areas where more research is needed to fully understand these environments. This study is important because it helps clarify the concept of living labs and suggests ways to improve their effectiveness in creating new solutions for public services.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-N2X3G6KR" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Living Labs, Public Sector Innovation, Co-Creation, Innovation Environments, Research Literature
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-N2X3G6KR" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    The public administration literature and adjacent fields have devoted increasing attention to living labs as environments and structures enabling the co-creation of public sector innovation. However, living labs remain a somewhat elusive concept and phenomenon, and there is a lack of understanding of its versatile nature. To gain a deeper understanding of the multiple dimensions of living labs, this article provides a review assessing how the environments, methods and outcomes of living labs are addressed in the extant research literature. The findings are drawn together in a model synthesizing how living labs link to public sector innovation, followed by an outline of knowledge gaps and future research avenues.
  </article>
